subject: redfish: Add Chassis listing associated drive
commitMessage:
redfish: Add Chassis listing associated drive

If chassis has drives a drive url is added to the chassis, of the form:
redfish/v1/Chassis/<chassis>/Drives

When queried, the drive URL will list all drives associated with the
chassis. This is in accordance with the redfish schema.

Samples for the following URLs are below

wget -qO- http://localhost:80/redfish/v1/Chassis/DC_SCM/Drives
{
  "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Chassis/DC_SCM/Drives",
  "@odata.type": "#DriveCollection.DriveCollection",
  "Members": [
    {
      "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Chassis/DC_SCM/Drives/mmcblk0"
    }
  ],
  "Members@odata.count": "1",
  "Name": "Drive Collection"
}

Tested:
With the redfish validator: No new errors

Change-Id: Ibdbe7fee5014d6515a77683c8eaca9ca86b6b148
Signed-off-by: John Edward Broadbent <jebr@google.com>

>

Talked with John earlier today.  This change isn't ready for review yet, he's going to rework some stuff and push a new patch.
Sounds good, one or two more changes.
Let me know if you see anything else
get rid of ct, and use resp.size()
Presumably these whitespace changes aren't something you intended?

$ clang-format-13 -i $(git ls-files | grep "\.[hc]\(pp\)\?$")^C
automatically makes this change.

I suppose you are on clang-format-12?

nit, for the sake of consistency does it matter that the argument to this lambda uses a type alias from include/dbus_utility.hpp but then in the body the type is written out instead of using the equivalent aliases from the file?

I hear you, and I changed it to dbus::utility::MapperGetObject type.

But the old form was very common, it was used several times in this very file.

see: 
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/53325/16..18/redfish-core/lib/chassis.hpp#240

I am fine with the change. I will keep it dbus::utility::MapperGetObject.

Yeah, we're not consistent on all counts;  At this level the consistency matters less.  It matters a lot more in the async_method call, because the difference between a const, const reference, or vector vs map ends up generating a lot more template code.
Please sort this list using the AlphaNum class (examples elsewhere) just to be consistent.  Ideally, if we can find a way to use getCollectionMembers, it will handle that for you.
odata.count is not described as a string, it's a number.  Service validator should've caught this.

I ran the redfish validator, and I did not see any warning related to this. 

I took a look at the validator, and did not feel close to finding this. So I created an issue to track this upstream.
https://github.com/DMTF/Redfish-Service-Validator/issues/491
The issue is fixed in the code, and a patch for the validator has been written.

This is basically the same code as getCollectionMembers (minus a couple bugs).  It's a slightly weird case because this is autoexpand, so the existing function doesn't work perfectly, but is it something we could use?

I see the similarities, in the code. 
The main difference is getCollectionMembers hard codes the  ObjectMapper interface, and calls GetSubTreePaths.

And my design uses the DBus.Properties interface and calls Get (via sdbusplus getProperty). 

It is possible to modify getCollectionMembers with default argument, or extract and share the iterative section of "getCollectionMembers" 

I have preference for getting this isolated change in, and minimizing the footprint of this change. Thoughts?
In conversation with Ed, he would like to see an effort made to using getCollectionMembers

Split getCollectionMembers, and use the iterative section. This is the clearest way to leverage getCollectionMemebers logic, in chassis.

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/53592

I wanted to use "+", but that darn presubmit makes me use +=

```
error: string concatenation results in allocation of unnecessary temporary strings; consider using 'operator+=' or 'string::append()' instead [performance-inefficient-string-concatenation,-warnings-as-errors]
```
https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-repository/42459/console
Construct your string on a separate line using operator +=.
Still incorrect.  This API is returning a DriveCollection, not a chassis.
not needed if we don't need to sort it.

why do we need to sort it?

The order is in the order that you expose it. Shouldn't it be control there instead?

Already answered

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/53325/19..22/redfish-core/lib/chassis.hpp#b819

Not if you want to pass clang 

```
error: string concatenation results in allocation of unnecessary temporary strings; consider using 'operator+=' or 'string::append()' instead [performance-inefficient-string-concatenation,-warnings-as-errors]
```

The core of the problem here is you shoudl be using the urlFromPieces method, not constructing a URI yourself with string +=.

With that said, if you still wanted to do that, you should ideally be constructing it on another line like we do elsewhere.

The patchset you commented on constructs a string in another line?

But I will switch to urlFromPieces.

shouldn't this be part of https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/redfish-core/lib/storage.hpp#L484.

just another endpoint?
actually, this is a collection, so maybe a new getDriveCollectrion

> shouldn't this be part of ..

I don't think so the url is /redfish/v1/Chassis/<ChassisName>/Drives/ only returns a list of drives that are in the chassis in question.
There is some shared logic, but most of that logic is in the getCollectionMembers logic, which can be unified across several places. And there is work in progress to do that.

> actually, this is a collection, so maybe a new getDriveCollectrion
I assume this is for the comment below, and yes.

The url starts with chasis, but it also returns drive information.
So I can change it from getChassis to getDriveCollection.

They are both privilegeSetLogin, under the hood
Yes, but in theory someone could override this to something else.

right, but by that logic the existing `getDrive` should be in `getSystems` or `getStorage` which might not make sense. Let's say that `getChassis` has stricter permission than `getDriveCollection` in that I can fetch `getDriveCollection`, but not `getChassis`. In that case, the user won't even know that this Chassis->Drive exists if it try to parse the redfish tree. Chassis is not exposed, so the link to the Drive is not exposed and such. At the end of the day, it would result in what you wanted.


And yeah, adding it to the closes privilege allow us more control over each resource.

> right, but by that logic the existing `getDrive` should be in `getSystems` or `getStorage` which might not make sense. Let's say that `getChassis` has stricter permission than `getDriveCollection` in that I can fetch `getDriveCollection`, but not `getChassis`.

In that hypothetical scenario, you would use the subpath overrides to declare the appropriate permissions for the "chassis drive collection" distinct from the "storage drive collection".  bmcweb doesn't do that properly today, so we latch everything back to the type interfaces.

> In that case, the user won't even know that this Chassis->Drive exists if it try to parse the redfish tree. Chassis is not exposed, so the link to the Drive is not exposed and such. At the end of the day, it would result in what you wanted.
> 
> 
> And yeah, adding it to the closes privilege allow us more control over each resource.
The key here is that which permission to use is controlled by the odata.type you're returning.

I never thought the permissions where very serious. How many people are using them?

That is interesting to think about. The behavior described by Willy is what I would want a system to do. However, the current patters (permission based on returned odata.type) is consistent.

> I never thought the permissions where very serious. How many people are using them?

Everyone?  There's no way to opt out of them at this point.


> That is interesting to think about. The behavior described by Willy is what I would want a system to do. However, the current patters (permission based on returned odata.type) is consistent.

What Willy suggests is for sure something that happens, and why subordinate overrides exist in the tree.  Yes, of course I can construct a PrivilegeRegistry that's nonsensical, but this code would still arguably work correctly if the nonsensical approach was used.

> but this code would still arguably work correctly if the nonsensical approach was used.

excellent (marked as resolved)
I also see no updates to the Redfish.md document documenting routes and parameters supported......  Something that's still coming?
Did this assocation get documented like we talked about?
don't we need to give a proper message to the user if there is no drive. Has it been taken care of already, if at all I missed.

If there are no drives, I would expect the too see
```
wget -qO- http://localhost:80/redfish/v1/Chassis/DC_SCM_noDrives/Drives
{
  "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Chassis/DC_SCM_noDrives/Drives",
  "@odata.type": "#DriveCollection.DriveCollection",
}
```
and the code above, should give us that result. 

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/53325/25/redfish-core/lib/chassis.hpp#782

What would your expect to see?
yes this is what  I was looking for. Thanks.

I think this still has an issue.  There's two options here:
1. If the chassis has no drives, omit the DriveCollection.  IN this case, a query to the DriveCollection for that Chassis should return 404.

2. If the chassis has no drives, always include a link to a DriveCollection, and in the cases where it's not present, will return an empty collection.

You seem to have done done a hybrid, where Chassis returns a link only if the drives are present, but DriveCollection doesn't return 404.  That needs resolved still I think.

Is there a standard way this is handled in bmcweb, empty collection vs 404.
I don't have a strong stance.

I set it to 404 because I suspect that is the typciall way empty collections are handled.

Unfortunately, there are two "standard" ways, the two I listed above.  If you're interested, this is something we could certainly make consistent, then have a rule for, but at the moment, both 1 and 2 are acceptable.

FWIW, my preference is for 2, because it doesn't require us to lookup the association twice (once for the chassis and once for the DriveCollection) but that's a minor preference.
okay, I changed it for option 2, empty collection.
don't we need to give a proper message to the user if there is no drive. Has it been taken care of already, if at all I missed.
As mentioned in a previous comment, I agree I don't think this should be in chassis.hpp

done. 

Thanks for looking this over.
yes this is what  I was looking for. Thanks
there are some type alias already defined, please use them

This has been brought up early in the review:
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/53325/16..28/redfish-core/lib/chassis.hpp#b771

I was unable to find a matching type. 
https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/b9d36b4791d77a47e1f3c5c4564fcdf7cc68c115/include/dbus_utility.hpp#L58-L83
We can add a type if we want, let me know what you want to do.
MapperGetSubTreeResponse isn't what you're looking for?

No,

MapperGetSubTreeResponse is 
```
std::vector<std::pair<std::string, MapperServiceMap>>;
```

But I need a 
```
std::pair<std::string,std::vector<std::pair<                                    std::string, std::vector<std::string>>>>
```

the subtree variable (that is being iterated on) is indeed a MapperGetSubTreeResponse

Let me know what your thoughts are.
I believe this line can be omitted

everytime we create a member list, we use this construction.

https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/45ca1b868e47978a4d2e8ebb680cb384e804c97e/redfish-core/lib/virtual_media.hpp#L188

But after reading some documentation it might not be necessary.
I am going test this again to make sure I can remove it.

Done.

Ed told me auto was best used when the type is explicit. ie, on the same line or line above.
As a general rule, bmcweb doesn't use auto, except in the most obvious of cases.  Having explicit types helps in code review when the types change.
interfaces is not referenced anywhere else, consider omit the variable creation?
I don't understand the question? I did not setup the association, I am only leveraging it here. What are you expecting?
please put the name of the association here.  It's new.

I added the name proposed in the PDI change "Drives", and added a link to the change. 
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/53676
In the naming convention here, this shouldn't include the HTTP verb.
done, the form I use here is used many times in this file.

I did a quick scan and didn't see any brace initialization;  Can you point one or two of them out?  Maybe I'm just blind.

Yes, there are quite a few instances of using string concatenation for building urls;  We're working on them.
Looks like this route has an instance of common error 11.

if an incoming request were to ask the mapper for chassis,  and the mapper produced  an error (either in the mapper or a the dbus level), I would expect 500. And that is what the code on 593 to 597 should do.

If the chassis is not found (but there were no errors), I would expect a 404.

> if an incoming request were to ask the mapper for chassis,  and the mapper produced  an error (either in the mapper or a the dbus level), I would expect 500. And that is what the code on 593 to 597 should do.

Unfortunately, your expectation here is incorrect with the coding standard, and what's documented in common error #11.  The mapper will return an error if no entries exist.

> 
> If the chassis is not found (but there were no errors), I would expect a 404.

The easiest way to test for this is to just drop a bad ID into your url;  it should return 404.  The code you had I'm pretty sure would not, because the mapper returns an error on non-existence.
Okay, I added a case that will check the ec, and if it is not found returns 404, otherwise 500.
You use urlFromPieces down below, I suspect you need to use it here as well.

I'm looking at this, and I'm not sure how this could've passed the service validator.  DriveCollection::Members is a Collection(Drive.Drive)

https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/DriveCollection_v1.xml

Which is an array of NavigationReferences, not an array of strings.  Can you please take a look at your test results, and try to make sense of why the validator is passing this?
Also, the url /redfish/v1/Chassis/<str>/Drives/<str>/ doesn't look registered in this patchset.  Please mention that the next patchset is also required to make this pass.

I bet I ran the validator when it looked like this
```
{{"@odata.id", "/redfish/v1/Chassis/" +                                               
    chassisId +
    "/Drives/" += leafName}});
 ```
 adding the "@odata.id", back
nit, in the naming convention this would be "chassisDriveCollectionGet"
Spoke with Ed, to make this list of issues.
change to "chassis<->drive", and remove gerrit review
One last thing.  Then this should be good to go.
Thanks for the quick review, let me know if anything else looks out of place.
